MAIN ESTIMATES, 1962 (Cont.)


    Head 50 -

    Question again proposed.

    Mr Ong Chang Sam (Choa Chu Kang(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister for Home Affairs yesterday stated in this House that the Government had lifted the ban of 8,000 books. All the books banned by the previous Government were unimportant and the Government hooks on which the ban had been lifted were of no significance. I said yesterday that the does not allow books of a political nature, such as books on socialism, to be imported into Singapore. The present Government professes to be a non-Communist, Socialist Party. The Prime Minister has also recommended that the people should read all kinds of books in order that they may learn how our society can be reformed. But the Government has so far not allowed books

Column: 2048

of this nature to be imported into Singapore. If the Government is sincere in reforming our society through knowledge gained from certain books on socialism and political theories, then it should allow the importation of such books into Singapore, as they will be very useful to the people of Singapore. If it wants to prove that a bad society can be reformed, then it should allow the people to read these books in order that they can decide for themselves whether the arguments put forward by the Government are good or bad. The present policy of the Government is contrary to its declared policy of promoting Malayan culture. The Minister for Culture and his Parliamentary Secretary have said that they want to encourage local writers to write books with a local background, as books of the nature of Alice in Wonderland are not useful and necessary in Singapore. The censorship on useful books imposed by the Ministry of Home Affairs had not been in keeping with the Government's professed policy. There is a book called Reminiscences of Fire which has not been properly censored. The present Government's policy is not in keeping with its professed aim of promoting Malayan culture. The Government should not adopt the same rule, the same standard or the same criterion in respect of the censorship of all kinds of books.

    Another point I want to raise is in connection with the issue of identity cards. At present, the Registration Centre sends out teams to register students in schools so that they do not have to come to the Centre for their identity cards. This is a good method, but, in actual fact, no proper facilities are extended to students, especially those in the rural areas. If the students who are promoted to secondary schools in the rural areas do not possess identity cards, the schools will not admit them. The Registration Centre has not sent out officers to the rural schools to register students who qualify for registration. When students went to the Centre, they were told by the officer in charge that they should remain in their schools and wait for the officers to come and register them. But no officer has ever been sent to the rural schools. The students in

Column: 2049

the rural schools have been inconvenienced because many of them will be going to secondary schools.

    So I hope the Minister for Home Affairs will take steps to facilitate the registration of students in order to enable them to proceed to the secondary schools in the urban areas. I hope he will provide them with all kinds of facilities to save their time and money.

    The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Ong Pang Boon)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not clear what books the Member for Choa Chu Kang was referring to. We have not banned books of a political nature. We have also not banned books on socialism. Many book-shops in Singapore are selling books on socialism. Perhaps he has not visited the book-shops, and that is why he is not aware of this fact. Perhaps he has visited those book-shops which do not sell this kind of books as they are not in great demand. The hon. Member could not point out any specific example, and that is why I cannot give a specific answer.

    Our policy on the censorship of books sold in the book-shops has always been liberal. We have been quite open-minded about it. I would like to quote a passage from the Report of the P.A.P.'s Special Committee reviewing the work of the Government and the Party. The Report clearly shows the attitude of the Government in regard to the censorship of books and literature.

    'It is contended that we have tended to be too strict in our censorship of books, films, records, music and other cultural material from abroad. Censorship is always a tricky problem as it very often involves a certain measure of subjective judgment on the part of individuals who exercise censorship. What may be immoral or undesirable to one group of people may not be so to others. Such differences of opinion are likely to arise in an even more acute form in a multi-cultural society where sense of values differ.

    In addition, censorship must pay regard to the prevailing political atmosphere and tensions in society. We must ensure that there is no expansion of cultural forces inimical to cur broad objectives of creating a Malayan nation and a democratic, non-communist socialist society.

    However, as long as these broad objectives are not jeopardised, there should be freer play of cultural influences.

Column: 2050



    There are cultural materials from abroad which are not merely propagandistic but calculated to bring about active hostility against democratic forms of government.

    We should restrict such type of cultural material as we restrict material which glorifies colonialism. The test is what impact certain types of hostile cultural materials is likely to have on our people at a given moment. For example, it may be all right to show a film dealing with religious and racial conflicts or about juvenile delinquency or gangsterism at times when there are no acute racial religious or juvenile delinquency problems.

    Works of literary and social, value, including those by Communists, should not be excluded as a matter of course. Only such works should be excluded which are likely to incite our people to do unconstitutional things or hamper us from our goal of building a Malayan society.'

2.45 p.m.

    The Chairman: Order. It seems to be a very long extract.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, there is only a short paragraph more to go.

    'Subject to this overriding consideration, we should allow freer flow of books, scientific literature, plays, films and songs from Communist countries. We recommend that all nonpolitical books should be allowed entry from Communist countries as a general rule.'

    Therefore, from what I have already quoted, we can see clearly that the Government's policy on censorship is very lax and broad-minded. Because of this, many books which were banned formerly are allowed on sale at present.

    As to the allegation that we do not encourage local creative works in literature, unfortunately the Member for Choa Chu Kang has not been able to give us any concrete examples in this respect. We have banned many undesirable publications imported from other countries. There is a positive aspect of this ban. If we have very few undesirable publications, then the healthy publications in our own country will have a good chance of better circulation. There will be more and more people trying to take part in literary works with a Malayan background. Therefore, in this respect, our policy is in compliance with that of the Ministry of Culture.

Column: 2051



    As for the book mentioned by the Member for Choa Chu Kang, Reminiscences of Fire, this was banned only at the time when the students were staging a boycott. This book contained seven articles, the first six of which are quite innocuous. But the last article, the title of which is Reminiscences of Fire, is the main reason for banning this book. It is because the writer of this article wrote about students camping in the Chinese High School in 1960. This article states clearly the organisation and activities of the students camping there, how they were trying to go against the Government at that time, and how propaganda work was carried out against the Government then. In this article terms such as "superior" and "Directives" which in Communist organisations were commonly used. Only those who were found connected with the underground activities of the Communists will have knowledge and use of such terminology. The event took place at the time of anti-colonialism, and the government then was pro-colonialist. But the present Government is a popularly elected government. The anti-government by violence phase has gone.

    Another reason for banning this book is that at the time when the book was banned there was a minority of Secondary IV students who made use of the same method of organising agitation among students in their boycott against Government Secondary IV examinations. They even resorted to violence to stop students Who wanted to sit for the examinations. So in that atmosphere of tension, if we allowed this book to circulate in the market, it would only lead to increasing difficulties for the Government. Therefore, I would like to ask the Member for Choa Chu Kang whether he is sincerely concerned with local writers with a Malayan outlook writing literary works in this perspective or whether he is trying to defend Communist activities. Unfortunately, he has not made it clear to me. I can tell him that fortunately it is we who are in power, otherwise the writer of this book will not be able to move about

Column: 2052

freely in this country. He might be confronted with more difficulties and troubles.

    As regards the Registry of Persons, the Member for Choa Chu Kang mentions that the Registration Office has not sent out mobile teams to rural schools to register the students who want to apply for identity cards. If there is such an occurrence, and if he can bring up concrete examples, such as the place or the name of the school or the students, then I will take proper measures to deal with such a problem. As far as possible, we are trying to reduce the need for 12-year old students from the rural areas to go to the Registration Office to get their identity cards. Many members of the public go to the N.R.I.C. Centre to get their identity cards. So if we encourage more and more students to go to the Registration Centre in the city, then there will be a great pressure of work. That is why we have decided that where there are students who are of age and who are studying in rural schools, we will send out mobile teams to register them so that we can save them a lot of trouble and transport money. Of course, we are understaffed and because of the question of expenditure, it is impossible for us to send out mobile teams to every school in the rural areas. I believe that given more favourable conditions, both administrative and financial, we will try to send out mobile teams to every school in the rural areas so that every student who wants to apply for an identity card can be attended to.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Mr Speaker, Sir, if the Minister were to have said yesterday what he said just now, I would have nothing to pick with him. In fact, I would have supported him. When he was attacked by the leader of the Barisan Sosialis in regard to censorship of publications and the denial of citizenship rights to be a number of what the Barisan Sosialis termed "anti-colonial fighters", the Minister felt it to be a very convenient way of answering such attacks by saying, "We are not so bad. It was the Lim Yew Hock Government that

Column: 2053

imposed the ban. Since we came into power, we have already approved about a few thousand books." Sir, in regard to that ban, may I explain here that it was a blanket ban on all publishing companies in Communist China? Then there was a continuing process of screening the books, and if the books were harmless they would be released for sale in Singapore. The P.A.P. took office in 1959 and the continuing process still continues. As a result of that continuing process, the ban was lifted from a large number of books.

    Coming to citizenship, the Minister said, "We are not so bad. The Lim Yew Hock Government was very strict. We have given citizenship to a lot of people." What the leader of the Barisan Sosialis said about the denial of citizenship rights was, I think, in regard to those who they claimed were anti-colonial fighters, and the Minister knows who they are. We refused to grant them citizenship. The fact that the P.A.P. has been in power for 2½ years, and coupled with the fact that those so-called anti-colonial fighters were comrades of the P.A.P. and they still refused them their citizenship rights shows that what the Lim Yew Hock Government did was quite right.

3.00 p.m.

    Sir, it has been the habit in this House since 1959 to label all sins or omissions on the Lim Yew Hock Government. Even the Barisan Sosialis, when they were sitting opposite, were attacking the Lim Yew Hock Government, as if it was a free-for-all. But now that they have come over here they are beginning to have the feeling, as the people of Singapore are now beginning to realise, that the Lim Yew Hock Government was not so bad as compared with the P.A.P. Government. At least, it is much better.

    The Chairman: Does the Member for Queenstown want a vote?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh (Queenstown): Can I speak a few words?

    The Chairman: Just a few words, and then we will take a vote.

Column: 2054



    Dr Lee Siew Choh: The Member for Cairnhill mentioned a little while ago about citizenship being denied only to certain people. But I can assure him that a number of students who took part in the 1955/56 demonstration have been denied their citizenship. Also quite a lot of people who were active members of the P.A.P., and not only those who were detained, like the Organising Secretaries and Branch Committee members, have been denied their citizenship. We do not know why.

    An hon. Member: All are Communists!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: As regards the books, Sir, may I ask the Minister how is it - this is in defence of the Member for Cairnhill in a certain way - that books which were available during the Lim Yew Hock period are no more available today?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: What are the books?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: Sir, a number of companies have been writing to the Minister for the last twelve months.

    The Minister for Culture (Mr S. Rajaratnam): Name the books.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: The names of the two companies concerned are the Singapore Trading Company and the Education Book Store. They have been writing to the Minister asking for certain hooks to be released. But they have not been released. In fact, during my stay in the Ministry, I found that if there is but one line in the whole book which says what is happening in China is good, or if there is just one line that praises Mao Tse-tung, then the whole hook is banned. So much so, Sir, that several people who had been working in the Ministry have resigned in protest. I feel that the Minister has borrowed spectacles heavily tinted from somewhere. Otherwise he could not have seen socialist books as Communist books.

Column: 2055



    Mr Ong Pang Boon: I did not know, Mr Speaker, Sir, that the Member for Queenstown has now allied himself with the Member for Cairnhill. My point is that in Singapore, unlike in the Federation, it is not a blanket ban as such. Books are released after examination. This Government has been more liberal. That is why within a period of two and a half years, we have released more than 8,000 books. In the Member for Cairnhill's time, probably none of those books would have been released. The Member for Queenstown has asked how it is that books which were available during the previous Government are no longer available now. Mr Speaker, Sir, there are many reasons why books which were available during the previous Government are no longer available now. It is not that we are even stricter than the previous Government. I would like to give some of the reasons why it happened. In June this year, I instructed my officials to find out about this, because certain allegations were made that nowadays book-shops have less books for sale than before. After interviewing five of the largest bookshops in the city, we found out that these are the reasons why there is a scarcity of books nowadays. First, once the books produced in China, are sold out in Singapore, they are no longer available in China. It is not possible to order again the same type of books because, in a planned economy, as in China, the production is related to the demand. Once the books are sold out, that is the end of it. Secondly, there is a shortage of printing material in China, and, therefore, it is not possible for the Chinese Government to produce as many books as before [Interruption] -

    The Chairman: Order.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: - for export overseas. The third reason, according to the bookshop proprietors, is that in recent years creative work in China has been very scarce. The reason is that many of these writers have been sent to the villages and the communes to take part in physical labour, and, therefore, they have no time to write any literary works. Hence, there are less new books

Column: 2056

available in Singapore. Mind you, Sir, this information was given by people who have been dealing with this business for years. Fourthly, the market for the progressive type of books is very small. Those who read them are the youth and the intellectuals. Mr Speaker, Sir, what all proprietors of bookshops are after is profit. If this type of books do not bring them as much profit as the others, they will not import them. Fifthly, although the Singapore Government has released many types of books, the Federation still imposes a ban on this type of books. Therefore, the market continues to be very small, and it is not profitable to import this type of books for sale in Singapore only. It is not because the Government's standard of censorship is more severe than that of the previous Government's. These are objective facts.

    The Chairman: Dr Lee, take a vote?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: One sentence only, Sir. I can summarise the real reasons in two words. They are the "Special Branch".

    Mr David Marshall: Hear, hear!

    The Chairman: Amendment (1) on the Order Paper Supplement for today. Inche Ahmad Jabri.

    Inche Ahmad Jabri Bin Mohammad Akib (Southern Islands)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 50 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 3.

    Mr Speaker, I am surprised to see that the vote for the cost of students attending the Muslim College at Kiang has been reduced as compared to the 1961 vote. What should have been done by the Government is to increase the vote and not to reduce it. This is on the basis of the policy to encourage more capable students to further their religious studies. It is, therefore, necessary that this vote should be increased. We have just heard how the Prime Minister replied to my question concerning translators in the High Court, He said there were not enough

Column: 2057

defendants, and so there was no need for more translators. I think those who receive religious study at the Muslim College, Kiang, will be more useful to the State of Singapore. Therefore, Mr Speaker, I think it is appropriate for the Ministry of Home Affairs to increase this particular vote, and not have the vote as it is this year. When I read today's newspapers, there are very few students studying at the Muslim College at Klang.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, when the Muslim College, Klang, was founded in March 1955, the Singapore Government made a capital grant of $10,000 and undertook to offer ten scholarships in' two batches of five scholars at the rate of $1,560 per year. The first batch of five students who joined the college in 1955 completed their studies in 1959. No scholarships were offered in 1960 because consideration was then given to reviewing the extent to which the Government had need of personnel academically qualified in the Muslim religion and the extent to which they could make use of the College. Unfortunately, this assessment of the demand for graduates of the College was not completed before the opening of the 1960 academic year of the College in April of that year. However, the matter was resolved and it was decided to send one scholar a year for the five years commencing from the 1961 academic year, instead of five scholars in one batch. The provision of $4,000 in the 1962 Estimates is less than previously because of the decision to send one scholar a year instead of five at the time. The provision of $4,000 in 1962 is to meet the cost of the student who studied in the College in the academic year 196l and will continue to do so in 1962, and the cost of the student who will be selected for the academic year 1962, and a little bit of other expenses that may arise in connection with their studies.

    The provision of $7,800 in the 1961 Estimates was only a repetition of previous estimates. At the time when the provision was entered in the 1961 Estimates, no decision had yet been

Column: 2058

arrived at whether to send one scholar per year or five scholars in one batch. That is the reason why there is this difference in the provisions for 1961 and 1962.

    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi (Kampong Kembangan): Sir, I feel at a loss when the -

    Sir, this is an item for the maintenance of vessels, and I find it difficult to understand why it is that the estimate for 1962 is double that of 1961. Is it because there are more vessels to be maintained or is it because the maintenance carried out from year to year has not been enough, and it has to be made up with a double vote?

Column: 2059



    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the provision is for the maintenance of the following vessels:-

    H.M.S. Laburnum, which is the Head-quarters ship of the M.R.N.V.R.; H.M.S. Panglima, H.M.S. Cana, Panji, two harbour launches, one fast motor-boat, three bailers and five dinghies.

    Until 1962, the proper maintenance of vessels has not been possible owing to the lack of funds and so maintenance on a breakdown basis only has been carried out. The slipping or docking has always been kept to a minimum because of high dock charges. Dock Staff therefore, have not been able to carry out drill tests or the examination of hulls and of associated fittings. This lack of proper maintenance in the past means that in most cases major overhauls will be required in 1962.

    In working out the amount required for maintenance of such vessels in 1962, estimates from the Harbour Board have been obtained and, as a result of these estimates, a figure of $138,976 has been arrived at. This maintenance comprises such items as scraping, painting, refitting of underwater fittings, replacing of waterline plates, cleaning, slipping, dock charges, etc.

    Dr Thio Chan Bee (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head 53 be reduced by $100.

    Sir, at the time of the Bukit Ho Swee Fire many people were asking themselves this question: Why should Government have to wait for a big fire before building houses to rehouse these attap-house dwellers? The Fire Brigade cannot control a fire that breaks out in an attap-house area if the wind is blowing strongly. Therefore, it would be a pity if the Fire Brigade is unable to prevent an occurrence like this once in three years, because if the money that has to be spent to relieve these fire victims could be spent before the fire, it would save the fire victims, the public and the Fire Brigade too, a large expenditure of money and effort.

    Another suggestion made is this, If the Fire Brigade could suggest preventive measures to reduce the fire risks in these areas, that would be another way to prevent a tragedy like this from happening regularly. I have been told, Sir, that in these attap-house areas if they changed the roofings of attap to zinc or aluminum roofings, then the Finance Ministry would come along and say that the property tax must be increased.

    The Chairman: We are now on the Fire Brigade and not on housing. Let us not talk about attap houses as against zinc houses. I should imagine that if the Member wishes to speak about the Fire Brigade on this vote, he should indicate how the Fire Brigade has failed, whether expansion is necessary and 50 on and so forth-not on housing.

    Dr Thio Chan Bee: Mr Speaker. Sir, the vote for the Fire Brigade comes to nearly $2½ million. If by preventive measures fire risks could be reduced, then we could reduce the expenditure. All this tragedy would not have happened. Simple measures like the Fire Brigade people going round to advise

Column: 2061

the people on changing their roofing would be of greater help. But there is one obstacle, Sir. The property tax people say this thing cannot be done without increasing the property tax. This is where perhaps one Ministry could help another.

    The Chairman: The Question is, "That the total sum to be allocated for Head 53 be reduced by $100." I do not know whether the Minister has anything to answer there.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, actually it is more a question of housing than the Fire Brigade. However, I wish to inform the Member for Tanglin that it is precisely because of these fire hazards that the Government is spending millions of dollars each year to build new flats, which will be more tire-proof, and we hope with the successful conclusion of the Four-Year Development Plan on housing, such large fires as the Bukit Ho Swee fire will not occur again.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Fire Brigade may be in a position to suggest ways and means of preventing fire, such as the use of inflammable materials for houses and so forth. But all this, Mr Speaker, Sir, is -

    The Chairman: Non-inflammable.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: - non-inflammable materials for houses and so forth. But, Mr Speaker, all this is to a large extent tied up with the economic conditions of the people. I mean, all the non-inflammable materials invariably are more expensive than attap and planks. Therefore, many of the suggestions of the Fire Brigade are just not within the means of these attap-house dwellers to carry out. That is where the Housing Board has come in to build low-cost houses for these attap-house dwellers.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I wonder whether the Minister could give some consideration to this suggestion. During the life of the previous Government some kampongs has fire extinguishers provided together with one or two firemen going round and forming a squad of about 20 kampong people

Column: 2062

depending on the size of the kampong, to teach them how to use these fire extinguishers and to be on call should there be a fire to prevent the fire spreading. I find that these fire extinguishers have now gone dry; the 20 people have gone off the list, and nobody knows who they are because the list has not been renewed.
